issues.text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was justified in holding that no services were rendered by M/s Gokul Nagar Sugar Mills Co. Ltd. to M/s Nawabganj Sugar Mills Co. Ltd.

holdings.text: There is no substance in these appeals as questions Nos. 1 to 3 raise purely questions of fact and no question of law arises.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that there is nosubstance in these appeals. No doubt, there is a resolution produced by the appellants dated July 26, 1944

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct reading of questions shows they challenge Tribunal's factual findings on services rendered by selling agent, consideration of specific evidence, and capacity of Dr. Narang; Tribunal is final on facts.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's findings are based on the material on record and could reasonably be reached on that evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court reviewed record including resolution, witness evidence (Ram Sahai Dhir via Ramdev telegram showing direct dealing, Shiv Nand Verma rejected as false since predates appointment), receipts (insignificant, only two over years, unexamined sub-agents).

holdings.text: The Appellate Tribunal has not omitted to consider any material fact or any material piece of evidence and acted judicially.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Udhavdas Kewalram principle that Tribunal must judicially consider all evidence for and against assessee; here Tribunal addressed key items (telegram, witnesses indirectly/directly, rejected unreliable evidence).

holdings.text: The Court agrees with the High Court that no point of law arises out of questions Nos. 1 to 3.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reinforces that challenges to Tribunal's factual findings on selling agent's services, evidence consideration do not raise legal issues warranting reference under s.66.

precedents.citation: Udhavdas Kewalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1

anchor.surface_text: The companynsel relied on the decision of this Court in Udhavdas Kewalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1 where it has been held that the Tribunal has to act judicially and companysider all the evidence in favour and against the assessee and that an order recorded on a review of only a part of the evidence and ignoring the remaining evidence, cannot be regarded as companyclusively determining the questions of fact raised before the Tribunal.

precedents.case_name: Udhavdas Kewalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: Appellants' counsel cited for the proposition that the Tribunal has to act judicially and consider all the evidence in favour and against the assessee and that an order recorded on a review of only a part of the evidence and ignoring the remaining evidence cannot be regarded as conclusively determining the questions of fact raised before the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and  1  1967 66 I.T.R. 462. pointed out that all relevant material on record has been taken into account by all the authorities, including the Appellate Tribunal and that the appellants can have numbergrievance in that regard.

precedents.case_name: Udhavdas Kewalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: Reporter citation for Udhavdas Kewalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City

precedents.citation: Udhavdas Kewalram v. Com- missioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-1 1

anchor.surface_text: As laid down by this Court in, Udhavdas Kewalram v. Com- missioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-1 1 the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal has to act judicially in the sense that it has to companysider with due care all material facts and the evidence in favour of and against the assessee and record its finding on all the companytentions raised by the assessee and the Commissioner in the light of the evidence and the relevant law.

precedents.case_name: Udhavdas Kewalram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: Court cited for the proposition that the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal has to act judicially in the sense that it has to consider with due care all material facts and the evidence in favour of and against the assessee and record its finding on all the contentions raised by the assessee and the Commissioner in the light of the evidence and the relevant law.
